messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, that sounds nice.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I already used it for the first question.

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Oh text input, I didn't even see that

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Okay
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Ok I'm ready
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I very much support these policies. I think that it would be useful to create more housing situations for people and lower the price of rent.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Positively, I think that reducing rent and giving people more homes is very, very positive. And reducing homelessness and people struggling to find places to rent. The only negatives that I see are maybe the increase of people causing more crime, more issues like parking, crowding, but I think that that's worth it for people to have more places to live.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I think they would greatly reduce the prices of them, which would make it much more affordable to people, especially those that need more affordable housing.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

It can be positive and negative. Positively, I think it will increase shopping at local businesses, but negatively, I think that it can cause more potential for more crime and more traffic, more overcrowding in the areas and schools and things like that. I think that overall it would be more beneficial than harmful.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

I don't know that it would make much of a difference because these are already problems so I think they already need addressed as it is and it might put a little strain on it at first but it might also put more pressure to actually address these issues.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
Listen to the public and their concerns and address them accordingly.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

I could see them factoring into it. Hopefully there's good practices in place with it to make people more comfortable about the environmental factor of it. But I think no matter where we would expand on housing it would cause the same concerns.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

I think that it would mostly be positive because it would help people be able to spend more money with the prices of rent being reduced and improve on quality of life which leads to better economic success.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think current residents should be taken into account more but future residents it should also be taken into account on what impacts this all would have. I think that it should all be looked at and judge what would be best for now and in the future.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I'm not entirely sure about this one. I guess that it would be a big part of it. I think it's important to make sure that people are comfortable.

How confident are you that changes in Creation of more housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that it would have a positive effect because upzoning would help create more housing and it would lead to Helping fix the housing problem, so I think it would strongly affect it
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

A major factor that influences that I think is seeing the high prices of rent and seeing homelessness. I believe that those very, very strongly influence people's support for upzoning and I would say that it's positive because it would increase the amount of places to live people would have and it would decrease the prices of rent so it would benefit people a lot.

Is the effect of Reducing Rent on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think that it would have a pretty immediate effect on the prices of rent if they start upzoning and it would have a very positive effect. That would be strong, like really strong, because people would see pretty fast that allowing it helps relieve a lot of that stress over finding a place to rent and the price of it.

Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Affordability has a positive effect because it would make people more interested in it just because things being more affordable is always better for people and I think that it's a very strong effect.

Is the effect of Positive impact on local businesses on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect on local businesses I think would take time to develop. It wouldn't really happen until people are living in these upzone buildings and are spending their money in the local businesses in the community. I believe that it's positive and over time it will have a strong effect because it'll make more money for these local businesses and probably open up more local businesses.

Does Existing transportation problems have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The existing transportation problems probably have a negative effect on support for upzoning. The significance is that people would probably be worried that a problem that's already there becoming worse is going to cause a lot more chaos with it, so I think that it could be a negative effect and quite strong.

How confident are you that changes in Strain on transportation systems lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I'm pretty confident that fixing this issue would also change people's support for upzoning. If there were a way to promise that some of the money that's being made by the companies that are upzoning is going back into improving the transportation systems, it would have a very positive, strong effect on increasing people's support for upzoning.

Would small changes in Local government role lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I'm not really sure about this one. I guess that it would help some, but I'm not entirely sure.

Does Urban density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't really think that urban density has a positive or negative effect on it. It could be either way because if things are already dense, people might not be worried about more. If it's not dense, people might not be worried about it, but it could go either way.

How would you describe the relationship between Improved quality of life and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it's a somewhat strong connection. More affordable housing would lead to a better quality of life, which, if that's promised with it, it would cause more support, and I think that would be a pretty strong effect on it.

Is the effect of Zoning decisions on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that it would take time to develop but I'm not really sure about this one and I think it could be positive or negative.

How would you describe the relationship between Comfort and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the relationship between comfort and support for upzoning would mostly be just because people would be more comfortable with lower rent prices and it's a somewhat strong connection and it would be positive because it would help people feel more comfortable because they're not spending as much of their money on rent.
What factors do you think influence Increasing Home Availability, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Some of the factors I think that influence increasing home availability or the price of them, people buying up houses and turning them into Airbnbs or rentals, are big issues in this area. I think that the impact is really strong for people just making Airbnbs out of places that usually would be rentals for people, very negatively affects availability of houses. I think increasing home availability would be very positive and beneficial to people because it would take stress away from people feeling like it's impossible to find a place to live.

How confident are you that changes in Homelessness lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I'm very confident that helping people not be homeless would definitely increase support for upzoning because it's becoming a bigger and bigger problem every year in this country and I think that it would make more people want to support it if they know that it's going to help ease that problem and I think that would be a very positive effect on it.

Does Positive effect have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
This question doesn't really make sense to me.

Would small changes in Immediate Effect lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I also don't really understand this question.

Would small changes in Immediate Effect lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Yes.

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
How do I send you a voice message?

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
When I click on the microphone button and speak, it does not record a message.

Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.

OK
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I oppose it, because it leads to higher congestion, garbage, and crime.  This has been shown to be true in many urban areas.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

It allows more people to afford their housing.  However, it also leads to more renters, and more lower-income people moving in, which leads to higher crime and other behavior problems.  People who have lower incomes tend to have lower self-esteem, which means they care less about their appearance and the appearance of the building.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
Those policies allow for higher population density, which lowers the rents, which means the housing is more affordable.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

It would definitely lower the quality of life, and change the character of the neighborhood for the worse.  This is because it would lead to more noise, congestion, trash, crime, and interpersonal disputes.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

You
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
So, I feel selfish saying this, but I do not want to live in a densely populated area. And I moved back here to my hometown specifically to get away from that type of environment.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

I think that the impact would be it would radically change the face of my neighborhood and it's already changing it. I, to finish the previous question, I oppose upzoning policies because it's already getting bad here and it's changing the character of my entire town and I really dislike it. I feel like if I wanted to live downtown I would live downtown. I don't want downtown to come to me.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

I'm against increasing the density in a residential neighborhood because people who live in neighborhoods live there because they want to live next to a tree not next to a wall. I already live too close to my neighbors. I'm really upset because I can't enjoy my backyard sometimes and I moved here specifically because I wanted to have a garden like just today for instance not to be gross but I could hear my neighbor having sex and that's disgusting and I don't want to hear it in my backyard. I want my right to peace and quiet enjoyment of my property which I already don't have because my landlady's a nightmare so I don't want to be going outside and having to hear my neighbor or having to smell cigarette smoke from a neighbor that moved in and is renting the property. I'm not opposed to renters. I am a renter myself. I think that there are good renters and quiet renters and people who are considerate of others but if I had to move back into an apartment building, not to be dramatic, but I would shoot myself in the mouth. I just don't want to live in that kind of proximity to other humans. I really dislike people and most of the time I really don't enjoy having to live even as close to them as I already do and if this upzoning thing goes through it's just going to be worse.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

I mean, I'm sure that it could make it more affordable, but I don't know if I really believe that because I'm in Austin, Texas. I don't know if I'm supposed to share that with you, but I hate Austin. I don't like what it's become. I really regret coming back here. It's just like Los Angeles now, and there's a lot of people here from there. It's basically a bunch of ugly condos going up that are probably still overpriced even though they say the rents are going down, yada, yada, yada. I don't know if I really believe that, but I think a lot of those condos are unoccupied and they're just like great, big, huge, giant. I mean, they're just apartment buildings. I don't know why they're called condos or whatever. It's just an apartment building is what it is. It's like an overpriced apartment building or like a fancy, bougie-looking apartment building, but when it comes down to it, you're still living on top of other people. I don't like the idea of that at all.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

It's going to ruin the character of the neighborhood. Right now, it's kind of out on the main road where the condos are, but I feel like they're getting closer. There's a hundred-plus-year-old farmhouse down the street that used to be a coffee shop I could walk to at the end of my street, and now it's being torn down to build another stupid condo we don't need. There's more than enough of them around here already, and I bet you they are not fully occupied at all.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

I mean, I don't really care how they affect the transportation systems, but ideally, they'll make the transportation systems more efficient, or I just think that they would cause, basically, just like everything else, just more demand on our resources and our natural resources. But I assume that if there becomes more densely populated areas, that the transportation systems are going to be more heavily used, which is going to require a lot more investment in the transportation systems and probably more traffic congestion, because people here love their cars. And, you know, even if you can't afford one, a lot of people still drive because the public transportation is not very good here.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

The local government should listen to its constituents, and I think a lot of their constituents are saying, no, we don't want this or that. Like for instance, my stepmother, because she hasn't worked in a long time, she kind of is a busybody and she used to try to protest things like a giant parking garage being built in their neighborhood because they don't want the traffic and they don't want this bar in a certain area because they don't want drunk people veering out onto residential streets. But all the things that they're against and that they campaign against, and I'm sure that they are contacting their representatives and they're voting for representatives that they believe will listen to them. It just seems to happen anyway, though. So I don't know, they've been trying to stop it or she's been trying to stop it, but it doesn't seem to be working. Whatever they want to build, they just seem to build anyway, and I don't live in the best area for politicians not being corrupt, so I don't really have much faith in the government.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

Environmental concerns are a very big deal to me. I honestly don't really want to know what I think about as far as the environment and people, you know, and then I'd have like Republicans jumping all over me saying, you don't like people. That's not true. I do like very few people, but I think most people are just a blight on the face of the earth and they're just destructive and they litter and they smoke and they drop cigarette butts all over the place and they pollute the air and they pollute the water and, you know, I myself am doing those things and I don't like it, but I feel like I do everything I can for the most part to try to make the environment, you know, my impact on the environment the least harsh as possible. I don't use pesticides. I don't use herbicides. I don't really use any bad chemicals if I can avoid it. I try to compost. I try to recycle. I try to reuse things. I try to not buy that much stuff. I hate plastic, you know, but I think most people just can't be bothered to even make any effort for the environment at all.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

It's changing in my area. I feel like, you know, like I said, these things are just going through, whether we want them or not. But I believe they did give consent for people to build a, what is it called, an ADU, basically like a mother-in-law or an additional house on their property. So I know it's going to make parking worse. I mean, I just feel like no matter what, eventually this is going to become Los Angeles, where I unfortunately had the misfortune to live for close to 20 years. And I just remember a lot of, you know, even though we lived in a residential neighborhood, having to constantly move my car, having to like read all these parking restriction signs, having to like not being able to park my car overnight to where I could sleep comfortably. I would have to get up and move my car because of the street cleaning. And then sometimes I had great difficulty even finding a place to park, or I'd have to find a garage and pay to park just to go home. Like I just, I remember like not being able to get home like at times because the traffic was so bad and like really having to use the bathroom. It was horrible. I didn't ever want to live like that again. And yet I feel like it's coming to where I am now. And I really, really hate that because I really don't want to mess with parking or loud neighbors or, you know, ruining my peaceful day because I hate my neighbors. You know, that type of thing. I just am not looking forward to it getting even worse. And I'm sure with people having multiple units on their property, although I'm sure the property owners are happy about it because that just means that they get more money and they don't even really need it. But you know, the more you have, the more you get. So I guess that's just the way the world works.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
It's time to perform. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

Does Neighborhood Character have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I really don't care about future residents. I really don't. Like, I don't think they should come here. I think there's too many people in the city. I think they should go somewhere else or if they really want to come here that badly, then they can just go downtown if they want to live around 100 million other people. But, you know, there's plenty of apartment homes. There's plenty of condos. If they want to go and fill those up, I'm sure they're not at capacity. I don't think we need any more right now.
What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

sure that there's some discussion about social equity and access to opportunity because there's always talk about you know converting some of these ridiculous condos or unused office buildings into homeless shelters i think they might have actually done that in one place but yeah i mean i'm absolutely in support of like tiny home communities or something like that but i think people need more livable areas like maybe not everybody wants access to a garden or even a community garden but i think it's better for everyone if we have more green space and you know leave the residential neighborhoods alone and let them be residential neighborhoods like maybe you know people really want to have one mother-in-law unit or something on their property then good for them but i don't think that it should get any worse than that because already we're seeing the neighborhood like people are building houses that are way too big for their lot size and and that's just with a single family home like if they're able to do that it already changes the face of the neighborhood there need to be better zoning laws because you know basically if you are in a single-story house someone can come along and build like a three-story house right next to you and it completely messes up your right to privacy and your view and your light and everything and that's happened um you know on both sides of my my dad and my stepmother's house so you know even without the additional units it's already messing us up because the zoning laws are all screwed up

Is the effect of Personal preference for low-density living on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

the economic effect of allowing more multifamily housing would be positive for businesses but it might be negative for residents so you know there might be higher property taxes or something I'm not exactly sure how that's gonna affect the single-family homes but you know it's not just about the economy it's about the quality of life and I think quality of life is more important than the economy and you know there's plenty of local businesses here there's plenty of people coming here we don't need to build a bunch more housing we should utilize what we already have I think we've overbuilt already and I think that actually the amount of people coming here is starting to slow because it's not as great as I think they thought it was there's actually a lot of drawbacks to living here not only politically but economically because there's a lot of utilities and you know the utilities are very high and the weather isn't great it's pretty horrible most of the year to be honest with you so I'm hoping that population growth will continue to slow

How confident are you that changes in Residential neighborhood density lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

neighborhood character has a negative effect on support for upzoning because it will mess up the nice residential neighborhood we have and change it into condo douchetopia and the effect is very significant so i think that except for maybe some homeowners who want the extra income of a additional unit on their property people are against it in the neighborhood just because it'll ruin the neighborhood to have all these big tall buildings here just like i think it's already ruined the neighborhood to have you know just regular single-family homes that are too big for the lot size and too tall

Would small changes in Desire for personal space lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

i understand this question it says is the effective personal preference for low density living on support for upzoning immediate i don't i don't see what it's asking but i mean i would think the personal preference for low density living wouldn't support the upzoning if you're talking about it taking time to change people's opinions yes that would take time um it would it depends on what you think a positive effect is if you think a positive effect is support for upzoning then i would think it would increase it i that this question makes no sense like how strong is the effect for personal preference for low density living that's a very strong effect a lot of us very strongly prefer low density living that's why we live in a low density area duh if we wanted to live in a high density area we'd live in a high density area and not in a residential neighborhood we'd go live downtown or go live in new york city or something she's

How confident am I that the changes in residential neighborhood density lead to changes in support for upzoning? I mean, how would that lead to support for uploading upzoning when people in a residential neighborhood don't want to be dense? I mean, it would, this also makes no sense. It wouldn't have a positive effect if people in a residential neighborhood supported upzoning. That to me is not a positive effect, but I guess it would have a positive effect on support for upzoning. Is that what you're saying? This makes no sense, but I don't think that people in a residential neighborhood support upzoning very much. I think it's just, if anybody, it's just the homeowners that want the ability to put more units on their property. I don't know anyone that supports it, but maybe the Californians from across the street who just moved here for an investment property want to like basically build an apartment building on their property so they can get more money and then just take that money and move somewhere else, you know, if they're concerned about taxes or something and just need to reinvest, that's probably what's going on. I feel like a lot of people in my neighborhood aren't even home, like they don't even live here and they probably just bought it as an investment property or maybe they're even in China or something like heck if I know, it's just weird.

Is the effect of Quality of life on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

All changes in desire for personal space lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning or would it take longer for larger shifts? I mean, you think people are going to desire less personal space? This isn't Japan. Like, why would we desire less personal space? I don't, I don't get this. Like, if, if you support upzoning, you must have a desire for less personal space because I don't support uploading upzoning. So it would be a negative effect. I, I don't desire less personal space. That's just a stupid question. It's a very strong effect because I don't want less personal space. because I don't want less personal space.

Is the effect of Austin, Texas on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Thank you. Thank you.

How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't see the traffic congestion going down here, because if we're talking about my area specifically, the traffic congestion is getting worse because people keep moving here, and then they keep messing with things like the 35, which is the main artery, the main freeway that goes through the city, so I don't think traffic congestion is going to go down. I guess, like, I don't even understand that thinking. I guess if they're thinking that people are going to live more in condos or something, that they're not going to have cars, because, trust me, they're going to have cars, so traffic congestion is going to go up, so I don't think it's going to increase support for upzoning, because the traffic's just not going to go down, and even if it did go down, I don't think people would make the connection.

How would you describe the relationship between Densely populated areas and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it's a strong connection if there is a relationship between densely populated areas and support for upzoning because if the area is already densely populated then chances are they need more housing and if they build more housing I don't think it's really going to bother people that much that already don't care if they live next to a tree because they would just want to live in a big apartment building downtown and be able to walk to everything as opposed to in a residential neighborhood where I would think more people are against it because we actually want to live next to a tree and not live next to a wall and not live next to a big slab of concrete.

How confident are you that changes in Zoning Decisions lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

How strong is the effect and Support for up zoning like I I don't think it would really change The effect if people are downtown and they want To live in a big city. They probably don't care. So I would think that the The strength would be neither positive nor negative. I would think it would just be neutral

How would you describe the relationship between Environmental Concerns and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think there's a strong relationship between environmental concerns. Well, a weak connection actually. So I would think environmental concerns would be against upzoning that would not support upzoning and that it would be a strong connection, but it would have a negative effect on the support for upzoning because most environmentalists don't want more buildings unless you're building a green space or a wild area or a wildlife refuge or you know a swamp like something so that the environment can regenerate itself instead of just building more space for people who make more waste.

Would small changes in Transportation system efficiency lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

No, I don't think small changes in the transportation system efficiency would lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning. It would take a larger shift because, like I said, I don't think people are going to make the connection even if traffic does improve. It would probably have a small positive effect on support for upzoning if it did improve, but I don't think it's very strong because I think most people are too self-absorbed to see that, oh gee, building all these new buildings has really helped with traffic, but I still don't think that's logical because living where I live, it's very car-centric and I think people will still continue to want their own vehicle as long as they can afford one. Frankly, I don't see how they afford one. I can't even really afford one, but somebody purchased one for me. Otherwise, I would probably be having to use public transportation, but I also strongly prefer to work from home, so maybe that's not as big an issue, but a lot of people now are being forced back into the office, so that might not work either.

How would you describe the relationship between Effect of Traffic on Upzoning Support and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Relationship between effect of traffic on upzoning support and support for upzoning. I think it's a weak connection because I don't think people make that connection. If the traffic were to improve a lot, it would have a slight positive effect, but people just saw it becoming a much more livable city, but I don't think that's going to happen. Also, it's not like the traffic's going to just magically get better and then they're going to support upzoning more. It's going to take a long time for traffic to get better if it gets better at all, and I don't think people will attribute that to upzoning. I think they'll attribute that to maybe someday in the distant future, they finally fix our freaking highway.

How would you describe the relationship between Urban Density and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The relationship between urban density and support for upzoning, I mean, if it's already dense, I would think it's a strong connection because people who live in a densely populated area probably don't mind living in a densely populated area and they'll probably continue to want to live in a densely populated area, unless I'm wrong. I would think it would have a positive effect, but not a very strong positive effect because people, I don't know, I think we already have a lot of urban density, so I don't see why those people care. I guess the only people that might care are the ones that live downtown, for instance, maybe don't want to live downtown anymore, but want to move somewhere a little bit more livable or a little more suburban. They might support upzoning because they want to be able to rent a unit a little bit away from the city, but I feel like if you live in the city, you live in the city because you want to live in the city and not in a residential neighborhood.

Would small changes in Public Protests lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think if there were a more public protest that maybe it would have a you know moderate effect a moderately strong effect on support for upzoning but I think it would take larger shifts because like I said people like my stepmother have been fighting this for a long time the ups fighting up sorry and also it's just it's just you know hard to fight back against big business here because the political the politics here are much more supportive of big business and like landlords than they are of small business or you know the little guy or you know tenants it's much more money driven here and doesn't seem to care as much about people's individual rights it's more about big business and people with a lot of money and so I just feel like that's the direction it's going because they're gonna cater to the interests of the 1%

Is the effect of Drunk Driving Safety on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of drunk driving safety on support for upzoning, I don't really see the connection unless you mean people being more in support of like walkable communities where people don't even have cars. Again, I don't really see that happening here. I don't think that people are making a connection between drunk driving safety and support for upzoning but maybe just because of the amount of people we have driving here and who still like go downtown and get drunk. You know, it could support it could be a weak, positive effect, increasing support for a more walkable city, I would think. But just with the culture here I see that taking a long time to develop and it not being a very strong effect because again I don't think people are going to make the connection right away.

Is the effect of People's Impact on Environment on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Effective people's impact on environment on support for upzoning Immediate no Yeah, it's probably more immediate than some of the other effects because people don't have to wait for something to show results to support the environment if you support the environment you support it and it has a Negative effect on upzoning I would think but I could be wrong I would think that it would decrease The support for upzoning because if you're building a lot more buildings and Generating a lot more waste that's not very environmentally friendly

How would you describe the relationship between Disapproval of Littering and Pollution and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the relationship between disapproval of littering and pollution and support for upzoning is like an inverse relationship. Because if you disapprove of littering, you probably don't support upzoning because if you have more people, you've got more problems. And it's a strong inverse connection and it would have a negative effect on support for upzoning because people litter. But I think it's also kind of cultural, to be honest with you, not to be racist, but it just is. I see a lot more litter in certain areas and certain minorities and I'm sure it just has to do with people's privilege. Because if they grew up in a crappy neighborhood where there's crap everywhere through no fault of their own and nobody ever taught them not to throw stuff on the ground, that's one thing, but if you grow up in a very fancy neighborhood with a HOA or something where people yell at you for having visible trash cans, you're probably less likely to throw things on the ground.

Does Use of Pesticides and Herbicides have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think use of pesticides and herbicides might go up with upzoning so it would have a negative effect. Although, you know, now that I think about it, people who live in apartment buildings or condos probably don't use as many herbicides as people in a residential neighborhood because they don't have anything to use it on or they have a very small garden area. So I would think maybe actually it's a negative... You know what? That's confusing. I would think it would have a negative effect on support for upzoning because if you're using pesticides and herbicides you probably have a house and a yard, but I don't think it's a very significant effect and kind of it's a weird question.

Would small changes in Composting and Recycling lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

This AI thing is just taking my thoughts and spiraling and it's not making any sense anymore. Small changes in composting and recycling, maybe I don't make sense, I don't know, and now it's making the AI not make sense. I don't think that composting and recycling is having a noticeable effect on support for upzoning. I think that people who support upzoning probably don't support composting and recycling as much because they're probably sitting in their single family home wanting to be in a single family home because they live in a single family home. Maybe people who compost and recycle are more altruistic, but I'm not. I'm just doing that for the planet and because I don't like people around and I would probably compost people if I were allowed to. I think it would take larger shifts to increase support for upzoning and it would have a negative effect because and a moderately strong negative effect just because like I said people who are composting and recycling are probably not in a apartment building but it could happen. I've done it before.

Would small changes in Composting and Recycling lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

qaPairs.question: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
qaPairs.answer: Sure.

qaPairs.question: You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
qaPairs.answer: Okay

qaPairs.question: For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
qaPairs.answer: Trying text input

qaPairs.question: You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
qaPairs.answer: yes

qaPairs.question: As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
qaPairs.answer: Thanks

qaPairs.question: Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
qaPairs.answer: You

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: So, I feel selfish saying this, but I do not want to live in a densely populated area. And I moved back here to my hometown specifically to get away from that type of environment. Therefore, I'm not a huge fan of upzoning.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: I think that the impact would be it would radically change the face of my neighborhood and it's already changing it. I, to finish the previous question, I oppose upzoning policies because it's already getting bad here and it's changing the character of my entire town and I really dislike it. I feel like if I wanted to live downtown I would live downtown. I don't want downtown to come to me. Traffic, noise, pollution, and litter all come with the package of upzoning.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: I'm against increasing the density in a residential neighborhood because people who live in neighborhoods live there because they want to live next to a tree not next to a wall. I already live too close to my neighbors. I'm really upset because I can't enjoy my backyard sometimes and I moved here specifically because I wanted to have a garden like just today for instance not to be gross but I could hear my neighbor having sex and that's disgusting and I don't want to hear it in my backyard. I want my right to peace and quiet enjoyment of my property which I already don't have because my landlady's a nightmare so I don't want to be going outside and having to hear my neighbor or having to smell cigarette smoke from a neighbor that moved in and is renting the property. I'm not opposed to renters. I am a renter myself. I think that there are good renters and quiet renters and people who are considerate of others but if I had to move back into an apartment building, not to be dramatic, but I would shoot myself in the mouth. I just don't want to live in that kind of proximity to other humans. I really dislike people and most of the time I really don't enjoy having to live even as close to them as I already do and if this upzoning thing goes through it's just going to be worse. I feel like upzoning might make housing more affordable, but not enough to offset the decreased quality of life or make it worth the sacrifice of the character of a residential community. It would just make the rich property hoarders aka landlords richer and less single family homes available for regular families because they keep being purchased by investors who do not care about the neighborhood other than for their personal profit.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer:
I mean, I'm sure that it could make it more affordable, but I don't know if I really believe that because I'm in Austin, Texas. I don't know if I'm supposed to share that with you, but I hate Austin. I don't like what it's become. I really regret coming back here. It's just like Los Angeles now, and there's a lot of people here from there. It's basically a bunch of ugly condos going up that are probably still overpriced even though they say the rents are going down, yada, yada, yada. I don't know if I really believe that, but I think a lot of those condos are unoccupied and they're just like great, big, huge, giant. I mean, they're just apartment buildings. I don't know why they're called condos or whatever. It's just an apartment building is what it is. It's like an overpriced apartment building or like a fancy, bougie-looking apartment building, but when it comes down to it, you're still living on top of other people. I don't like the idea of that at all.

It's going to ruin the character of the neighborhood. Right now, it's kind of out on the main road where the condos are, but I feel like they're getting closer. There's a hundred-plus-year-old farmhouse down the street that used to be a coffee shop I could walk to at the end of my street, and now it's being torn down to build another stupid condo we don't need. There's more than enough of them around here already, and I bet you they are not fully occupied at all.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: I mean, I don't really care how they affect the transportation systems, but ideally, they'll make the transportation systems more efficient, or I just think that they would cause, basically, just like everything else, just more demand on our resources and our natural resources. But I assume that if there becomes more densely populated areas, that the transportation systems are going to be more heavily used, which is going to require a lot more investment in the transportation systems and probably more traffic congestion, because people here love their cars. And, you know, even if you can't afford one, a lot of people still drive because the public transportation is not very good here.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: The local government should listen to its constituents, and I think a lot of their constituents are saying, no, we don't want this or that. Like for instance, my stepmother, because she hasn't worked in a long time, she kind of is a busybody and she used to try to protest things like a giant parking garage being built in their neighborhood because they don't want the traffic and they don't want this bar in a certain area because they don't want drunk people veering out onto residential streets. But all the things that they're against and that they campaign against, and I'm sure that they are contacting their representatives and they're voting for representatives that they believe will listen to them. It just seems to happen anyway, though. So I don't know, they've been trying to stop it or she's been trying to stop it, but it doesn't seem to be working. Whatever they want to build, they just seem to build anyway, and I don't live in the best area for politicians not being corrupt, so I don't really have much faith in the government.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: Environmental concerns are a very big deal to me. I honestly don't really want to know what I think about as far as the environment and people, you know, and then I'd have like Republicans jumping all over me saying, you don't like people. That's not true. I do like very few people, but I think most people are just a blight on the face of the earth and they're just destructive and they litter and they smoke and they drop cigarette butts all over the place and they pollute the air and they pollute the water and, you know, I myself am doing those things and I don't like it, but I feel like I do everything I can for the most part to try to make the environment, you know, my impact on the environment the least harsh as possible. I don't use pesticides. I don't use herbicides. I don't really use any bad chemicals if I can avoid it. I try to compost. I try to recycle. I try to reuse things. I try to not buy that much stuff. I hate plastic, you know, but I think most people just can't be bothered to even make any effort for the environment at all.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: I'm sure the business owners would be happy to have more customers, but there would be a heavier burden on infrastructure and demands on the environment and the school system, etc. It's changing in my area. I feel like, you know, like I said, these upzoning/coding changes are just going through, whether we want them or not. But I believe they did give consent for people to build a, what is it called, an ADU, basically like a mother-in-law or an additional house on their property. So I know it's going to make parking worse. I mean, I just feel like no matter what, eventually this is going to become Los Angeles, where I unfortunately had the misfortune to live for close to 20 years. And I just remember a lot of, you know, even though we lived in a residential neighborhood, having to constantly move my car, having to like read all these parking restriction signs, having to like not being able to park my car overnight to where I could sleep comfortably. I would have to get up and move my car because of the street cleaning. And then sometimes I had great difficulty even finding a place to park, or I'd have to find a garage and pay to park just to go home. Like I just, I remember like not being able to get home like at times because the traffic was so bad and like really having to use the bathroom. It was horrible. I didn't ever want to live like that again. And yet I feel like it's coming to where I am now. And I really, really hate that because I really don't want to mess with parking or loud neighbors or, you know, ruining my peaceful day because I hate my neighbors. You know, that type of thing. I just am not looking forward to it getting even worse. And I'm sure with people having multiple units on their property, although I'm sure the property owners are happy about it because that just means that they get more money and they don't even really need it. But you know, the more you have, the more you get. So I guess that's just the way the world works.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: I think the needs of the existing residents should carry a lot more weight than people just coming here. If they don't like how the area is they can choose someplace more in line with their preferences, but people in this area might have lived here for generations, might be elderly, or may not have the ability to just pick up and move somewhere else. Why fix what isn't broken. I feel very NIMBY about this, but it is literally my backyard, and the area already feels much too dense, it could only get worse.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: I think social equity plays a big role in discussions about zoning and housing policy. There is a lot of gentrification happening here, especially in East Austin, a historically black neighborhood that has been hipster-fied, and now the previous residents can't afford it anymore (and neither can I, sadly).

Neighborhood Character has a strong negative effect, one would hope. Too much change too fast is not a good thing. I really don't care about future residents. I really don't. Like, I don't think they should come here. I think there's too many people in the city. I think they should go somewhere else or if they really want to come here that badly, then they can just go downtown if they want to live around 100 million other people. But, you know, there's plenty of apartment homes. There's plenty of condos. If they want to go and fill those up, I'm sure they're not at capacity. I don't think we need any more right now.

I'm sure that there's some discussion about social equity and access to opportunity because there's always talk about you know converting some of these ridiculous condos or unused office buildings into homeless shelters i think they might have actually done that in one place but yeah i mean i'm absolutely in support of like tiny home communities or something like that but i think people need more livable areas like maybe not everybody wants access to a garden or even a community garden but i think it's better for everyone if we have more green space and you know leave the residential neighborhoods alone and let them be residential neighborhoods like maybe you know people really want to have one mother-in-law unit or something on their property then good for them but i don't think that it should get any worse than that because already we're seeing the neighborhood like people are building houses that are way too big for their lot size and and that's just with a single family home like if they're able to do that it already changes the face of the neighborhood there need to be better zoning laws because you know basically if you are in a single-story house someone can come along and build like a three-story house right next to you and it completely messes up your right to privacy and your view and your light and everything and that's happened um you know on both sides of my my dad and my stepmother's house so you know even without the additional units it's already messing us up because the zoning laws are all screwed up.
qaPairs.question: Does Neighborhood Character have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Neighborhood Character → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer:
Neighborhood Character - strongest - negative
Business Interests - strong - positive

qaPairs.answer: the economic effect of allowing more multifamily housing would be positive for businesses but it might be negative for residents so you know there might be higher property taxes or something I'm not exactly sure how that's gonna affect the single-family homes but you know it's not just about the economy it's about the quality of life and I think quality of life is more important than the economy and you know there's plenty of local businesses here there's plenty of people coming here we don't need to build a bunch more housing we should utilize what we already have I think we've overbuilt already and I think that actually the amount of people coming here is starting to slow because it's not as great as I think they thought it was there's actually a lot of drawbacks to living here not only politically but economically because there's a lot of utilities and you know the utilities are very high and the weather isn't great it's pretty horrible most of the year to be honest with you so I'm hoping that population growth will continue to slow

neighborhood character has a negative effect on support for upzoning because it will mess up the nice residential neighborhood we have and change it into condo douchetopia and the effect is very significant so i think that except for maybe some homeowners who want the extra income of a additional unit on their property people are against it in the neighborhood just because it'll ruin the neighborhood to have all these big tall buildings here just like i think it's already ruined the neighborhood to have you know just regular single-family homes that are too big for the lot size and too tall

All changes in desire for personal space lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning or would it take longer for larger shifts? i understand this question it says is the effective personal preference for low density living on support for upzoning immediate i don't i don't see what it's asking but i mean i would think the personal preference for low density living wouldn't support the upzoning if you're talking about it taking time to change people's opinions yes that would take time um it would it depends on what you think a positive effect is if you think a positive effect is support for upzoning then i would think it would increase it i that this question makes no sense like how strong is the effect for personal preference for low density living that's a very strong effect a lot of us very strongly prefer low density living that's why we live in a low density area duh if we wanted to live in a high density area we'd live in a high density area and not in a residential neighborhood we'd go live downtown or go live in new york city or something sheesh.
