messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, please.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Sounds good

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Sure.

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Sounds good
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
That's the first question.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

Well, you know, I support upzoning in the single family neighborhoods, especially in San Francisco. You know, I was born and raised there. I grew up in the Sunset and I now live up in Diamond Heights. So I've been, I've seen firsthand how hard it's gotten for regular people to live in the city they love. Upzoning doesn't mean tearing down, you know, every single home or ruining neighborhoods. It means giving people more chances to stay, build a life, and perhaps raise a family here. We definitely need more housing options, period. And we're not just talking luxury high-rises, but, you know, homes that real working people like myself can actually afford. If it's done right, you know, upzoning can really help us get there.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Well, you know, the biggest impact of increasing housing density is probably that more people have a real shot at living in San Francisco. And that's definitely an upside. You've got more homes, you've got more neighbors and, you know, hopefully more diversity. We priced out so many folks already, you know, with that booming tech industry that we have, you know, but it doesn't have to be that way all the time. Obviously, the downside is how change affects our feelings. And people do worry about losing something that's familiar, that's quiet, you know, the space, the parking. And if we're not careful, developers might just build for profit and not really for the people. So the key is definitely smart planning, you know, build the neighborhood in mind and not just build a skyline.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

We know upzoning could help with affordability, but only if it's done with the right intentions. Just allowing more units to go up doesn't guarantee cheaper rent. We've seen that before. But if the city ties upzoning to real affordable housing, like units that teachers, nurses, flight attendants, and working families can actually afford, then it definitely can make a real difference. More supply does help, but we need rules that make sure that supply works for those people who actually need it, like my children. Otherwise, it's just more expensive condos being stacked on top of each other, something like Hong Kong.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

You know more housing density it's gonna definitely change how some of our neighborhoods look. You got these taller buildings you know definitely more people maybe even a little bit more noise but that doesn't necessarily mean you know it's gonna ruin the character of San Francisco and in some ways it can actually bring it back, bring back its character. A lot of San Francisco spirit comes from people you know families, immigrants, artists, small business owners. You know if we don't make room for those kind of people the city becomes less attractive, not necessarily more attractive. So yeah I think the neighborhood might feel a little bit different but if done right you know the quality of life definitely can improve. Lots of local shops, better transit, more energy, maybe more funding too.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

Well, you know, upzoning, it's a given that there's going to be more people. And that definitely means, you know, more traffic if you don't plan ahead. But it's also a chance to do things a lot smarter. If we build near public transit, you know, make it easy to walk or bike, we don't have to add much to the gridlock. In fact, we might actually reduce it. More people living close together where they work or shop means, you know, fewer cars on the road. The real issue is making sure our transit system keeps up, like BART and MUNI and buses, you know, things like that, you know, bike lanes, in fact. They need to grow with the city, you know, upzoning can help or hurt, you know, it really just depends on whether, you know, you build just more units or you actually invest in how people move and travel.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

You know, I think local government should definitely lead and not react. They're the ones who, you know, know the community is the best, supposedly. It's why we voted for our leaders in local government. They definitely should set clear rules, ensure that new housing fits the needs of the people of San Francisco and hold developers accountable. It's not just about how many units get built, as I said before. You know, it's about what gets built, where, and for who it gets built for. You know, local leaders should protect longtime residents from being pushed out while still making room for new families trying to build a future here. You know, it's why I voted for them. Bottom line, you know, government should be the guardrails and perhaps the guide, not just an automatic rubber stamp.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

You know, environmental concerns definitely should be at the forefront and center when we talk about zoning and density. More people in a smaller footprint can actually be better for our planet. You know, fewer long commutes, less sprawl, and perhaps more walkable neighborhoods with parks and trails. But if we don't plan smart, you know, the risk is going to make things worse, like losing green space, putting pressure on old infrastructure, maybe buildings in ways that don't hold up to climate change. Density can be sustainable, but only if we definitely think long term. You know, that means energy efficient buildings, better transit, and protecting what nature we have in the city.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

You know when you're changing zoning laws to allow for more multi-family housing, it sometimes can help the economy in many ways. You have more housing and that usually means more jobs in construction, means more customers for local businesses, means more people who can afford to live in there where they work and you know Bay Area is very very expensive. That's good for the city but as I've stressed all along, if we don't do it correctly it's gonna drive up land values and push out longtime residents, perhaps my children and even myself and small businesses that can't keep up with the rising costs. We've seen this before so yeah I mean there's economic potential but only if we keep it fair, keep it local and ensure that the benefits don't just go to the top.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

Well, you know, it's not easy, let's be real. But both matter and both deserve a seat at the table. Current residents built these neighborhoods, which is my mom and dad, when they purchased property here, lots of it. They've got roots, stories and memories here, you know, they, they shouldn't be ignored or pushed out. At the same time, we can't freeze the city in time. You know, future residents are part of San Francisco story too, you know, it's the next generation that will define what San Francisco really is. People are just staying here, just trying to live here, raise families and, you know, fresh start. We have to make space for those people too. Zoning decisions should protect what's special about a place and, you know, create room for what's next. It's not either or, it's usually making sure growth doesn't create elimination or ratio.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

Well, in my opinion, I think society, equity, and access to opportunity should all be at the heart of any housing policy or at its core. Zoning isn't just about the pretty buildings or the architecture. It's about who gets to really live here and who gets left out, and the haves and the have-nots. For far too long, zoning laws have been used to keep certain people out, especially low-income families, immigrants, and people of color. That's just bad policy. It's definitely wrong. Housing is an opportunity. It's access to good schools, clean air, good jobs, and a real shot at stability. If we really care about fairness, we have to fix the system. Housing should open those doors and build invisible fences.

How would you describe the relationship between Affordable housing and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The connection between affordable housing and support for upzoning is certainly real. But it also depends on the trust. When people believe upzoning will actually lead to affordable homes, not just mere expensive condos, flashy buildings, they're more likely to support it. So yes, if we have a strong positive effect. But if the community sees real guarantees, and they might go along with it, they don't just want empty promises. Zoning feels like it's a developer free-for-all, support drops really quickly. People don't like change, they're usually against change. They're definitely against being priced out of it. So the effect is strong, but it sinks hard in either direction, depending on how honest and fair the process feels.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Well, you know, support for web zoning goes up when people see it tied to real solutions like affordable housing, you know, better public transportation, better protections for long-time residents. When folks see real benefits, you know, for their community, you know, support obviously grows. It goes hand in hand. Now that's a positive, increased influence. Now the support quickly drops off the cliff when upzoning feels like it's just, you know, going toward the developers and lining their pockets or it changes the neighborhood without any say among the people living there. Displacement, rising rents, and certainly a lack of trust in city leaders are a negative decreasing effect and really hit hard. So yeah, it can swing and it can swing big in either direction. It really depends on whether people believe the change will help them or not just someone else.

Is the effect of Diversity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of, you know, diverse support for upzoning does take time, let's be real. You know, it doesn't happen overnight. People need to really hear from the voices they trust, you know, like the neighbors, the community leaders, and not just the politicians or developers or the bigwigs. When support comes from a mix of people, different backgrounds, ages of all kinds, incomes, it really does build confidence. That has a positive increasing effect. It tells folks, hey, this isn't just for them, it's for all of us. It's really that strong effect, but it grows slowly. It's earned, and it's not handed out freely. And when people see that others like them are being heard and considered, support starts to take a foot, and they start feeling they're taken advantage of, and it's lining the coffers of the big boys, you know, they're likely not to support.

How would you describe the relationship between Housing affordability and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, you know, the connection between, you know, housing affordability and support for upzoning is a pretty strong connection, but, you know, it's built on what people believe upzoning will actually do. Folks see upzoning as a way to bring prices down and create homes they or their kids can afford support increases like myself. That's a true positive fact. But if they think it just leads to more high-end buildings and higher rents, then support's going to drop. And I've seen that before. And that's definitely a negative effect. So, you know, the effect is strong either way. It just depends on whether people trust that upzoning is part of a solution and not just a part of the problem.

Is the effect of Taller buildings on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, you know, the effect of taller buildings on support for up-zoning is almost immediate. People are going to react fairly quickly when something new shows up on their block and it's a tall one. Now for a lot of folks, it has a negative decreasing effect, you know, not in my backyard. They worry about shadows, parking, views, and the feel of the neighborhood changing too fast. That reaction can be very, very strong, especially if they weren't part of that decision. But over time, you know, if these buildings bring real benefits like affordable homes or new local shops, opinions, you know, can't shift still. That first impression, you know, it hits hard. So yeah, the effect is immediate and strong, usually negative, unless the city does a really good job of selling it or trying to explain the why and showing the who it's for, you know, how's it going to benefit me.

Does Traffic Congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well you know traffic congestion has a negative decreasing effect on support for upzoning and that's just a reality when people already feel stuck in traffic and just sitting there. The idea of adding more people to the area makes them nervous you know it's just a gut reaction and it's a very strong one and even if upzoning brings benefits you know folks worry it'll just make the roads worse. So unless the plan includes real transit improvements such as bike lanes, walkable options, more efficient bus routes, extension of BARTA metro your support tends to wane. So yeah it's a strong negative effect unless you fix the traffic story first.

Is the effect of Community knowledge on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, the effective community knowledge on support for upzoning takes time to develop. People don't just flip their opinions overnight, like it's a dream. They need to understand that what's being proposed, to analyze it, to absorb it, and how's it going to affect them, whether it's fair, it's all about me, and how's it affect me? When folks are informed and feel included, you're going to have a positive increasing effect on that support. They're more open to change when they know what's the reason behind it and how they see benefit as a community, as a whole, not just for developers. It's a strong effect, but it builds slow. Trust does take time. It doesn't build overnight. Good information, shared early and often, is what really makes the difference.

Does Urban density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

You know, urban density can cut both ways. In areas that already feel crowded, it tends to have a negative effect, a decreasing effect on support for upzoning. You know, people often worry about, you know, way too many people, and there's not enough parking, pressure on schools or transit, that direction is often immediate and strong, you know. Being a lifelong resident of San Francisco, I can definitely tell you, you know, that reaction, if they see that, you know, they're not going to like it. But in places where density brings walkability, better public services, and local business, the effect can be positive, increasing, you know, especially when people see the benefits for themselves. So the effect of density on support for upzoning is significant. It's rather strong either way. It just really depends on whether people feel the growth is helping or overwhelming their particular neighborhood.

Is the effect of Sustainable development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, you know, the effect of sustainable development and support for upzoning takes time to develop. People need to see the proof, energy efficient buildings, green space, better transit, you know, less waste. It's not something that clicks right away, but once you see it's in action, it has a positive increasing effect. When upzoning is tied to sustainability, folks are definitely more likely to support it, especially if, you know, they care about climate, you know, quality of life and especially long-term planning.

Does Construction jobs have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

You know, construction jobs usually do have a positive, increasing effect on support for upzoning. You know, especially in working class communities or places hit hard by unemployment, you know, people see jobs, they may see paychecks, you know, see local hiring as a big win, you know, when you have increasing jobs available, that's always a win for any community. But it's not a huge driver on its own, you know, it's got a moderate effect. Folks will care more about what's being built and who can live there and the sustainability and its impact on their daily life. So yeah, construction jobs do help build support, but, you know, the flip side, it only, you know, if you look at the big picture, you know, it has to feel fair and beneficial.

Is the effect of Displacement of longtime residents on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

You know, the effect of displacement on support for upstarting is quite immediate. It's negative. When long-term residency neighbor is forced out, you know, that trust breaks down quickly. And people don't wait to see the long-term benefits, they react to what they see now and what's happening now. It's a very strong effect. You know, displacement makes folks feel like the city is being taken from them, you know, not shared. And especially those, you know, who have been there a long time. Even if the policy has good intentions, if people see their community as being erased in support for upzoning, it disappears very quickly. But unless, you know, protections are built from the start, displacement kills trust and definitely support within it.

Is the effect of Community memory and history on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

You know, the effect of memory and history or support for upzoning takes time to develop. We've always stressed that. It's built for the people and it's built into the people. The stories, the landmarks, the way a place feels because of who's lived there. For many, it has a negative effect on upzoning, especially if the change feels rushed and if it's incomplete, like it's swiping out the past. People want to protect what they've known and loved for so many years. That feeling can be strong, especially in neighborhoods with deep roots. But if upzoning respects that history, you know, not just with plaques and trophies and all those kind of things, but with actual real care, the resistance can soften over time. Still, memory runs deep, and if you ignore that, the support fades very, very quickly.

How confident are you that changes in Access to Opportunity lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, you know, it's very confident, I'm very confident that, you know, changes in access to opportunity, ATO, you know, leads to changes in support for upzoning. When people see that, you know, upzoning brings real opportunities, like better schools, shorter commutes, more parks and recreation, job access, retail, safer housing, you know, support will increase and that's a positive effect and it can be strong, especially in underserved communities, you know, but the key is who gets that access, you know, if only new arrivals or wealthier folks with big pockets benefits and then only benefits them, then, you know, support dwindles fast. So, yes, access to opportunities has a big impact, but also not only if it's shared.

Does Housing Policy have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, housing policy usually has a positive increasing effect on support for upzoning. If the policy is clear, fair, and it actually helps people and they believe it. When folks see strong policies that protect renters, fund affordable housing, and prevent displacement, strong support for upzoning does go up, and that's a very strong effect. Reviewed policy builds great trust, but when housing policy is weak, confusing, and feels like it only helps the developers with thousands of millions of dollars, the support drops quick like a rock, drop it like it's hot. So while the effect is significant, it really depends on how well the policy is written and enforced.

What do you think are the main causes of Increased housing availability, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Well, you know, the main cause of increased housing availability, you know, right now are upzoning and relaxed building regulations, you know, letting more units get built faster without really thinking about things. You know, so I guess that can be a positive increasing effect, but I'm fairly certain about this. It's happening in real time across the, you know, cities, you know, public and private investment in affordable housing, more funding, more units, et cetera, you know, positive increasing effect, you know, I'm only certain depends on whether funding actually reaches the right projects, you know, higher interest rates, slowing demand. Some buyers are sitting it out, you know, leaving more rental openings, you know, a mixed effect, you know, can increase availability, but not necessarily affordability. I am somewhat certain it's a side effects. It's not a longterm fix, remote work shifts, you know, fewer people needing to live in these high cost urban dense areas, you know, positive, you know, it has a positive increasing effect in some cities, neutral in others, you know, moderate certainty still is playing out. So, yes, multiple things are pushing availability up, but, you know, only those of them are truly sustainable or equitable and, you know, housing doesn't stay down for long, especially in San Francisco.

How would you describe the relationship between Community trust and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, you know, the relationship between community trust and support for upzoning is fairly, fairly strong. Maybe one of the strongest there is when people trust the city and planners and the process and the support for upzoning does increase, you know, that's a positive effect. And it grows fast when folks get heard, respected and protected. But when trust is broken, you know, when decisions are made behind closed doors or people get displaced without wanting it and feel like things to come down behind their back, you know, support really drops fast and hard. That's a negative decreasing effect and it's just as strong as if not stronger. So yeah, you know, community trust doesn't just influence support for upzoning, it really decides it.
What causes changes in Upzoning policies? Are these influences strong or weak?

Changes in upzoning policies usually happen because of a mixed pressure of politics and public needs. And the main causes generally tend to be, I think, housing shortages and an affordability crisis. That's definitely a strong influence. You know, enough people can't afford to live in a city, something's got to give to get priced out. So, you know, you get political leadership and city priorities that are definitely a strong influence. A mayor or city council pushing for change can shift that policy or maybe just entirely block it. I think, you know, community pressure and advocacy is a moderate to strong influence. If neighborhoods organize and push for more inclusive housing, it can definitely move the needle. You know, also, you know, especially when the media picks it up. And then you get the developers and business interests, strong influence, but sometimes controversial. They bring money and momentum, but not always the community, it's a buy-in. And then you get the state or federal mandates, strong and growing influences, especially in cities like California, you know, where the state is stepping in when the city calls or city solve. So yeah, most of these influences are strong. The question is whether they're being used to help everyone or just a few.

Upzoning doesn't mean tearing down, you know, every single home or ruining neighborhoods. It means giving people more chances to stay, build a life, and perhaps raise a family here. We definitely need more housing options, period. And we're not just talking luxury high-rises, but, you know, homes that real working people like myself can actually afford. If it's done right, you know, upzoning can really help us get there.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Obviously, the downside is how change affects our feelings. And people do worry about losing something that's familiar, that's quiet, you know, the space, the parking. And if we're not careful, developers might just build for profit and not really for the people. So the key is definitely smart planning, you know, build the neighborhood in mind and not just build a skyline.

We've seen that before. But if the city ties upzoning to real affordable housing, like units that teachers, nurses, flight attendants, and working families can actually afford, then it definitely can make a real difference. More supply does help, but we need rules that make sure that supply works for those people who actually need it, like my children. Otherwise, it's just more expensive condos being stacked on top of each other, something like Hong Kong.

A lot of San Francisco spirit comes from people you know families, immigrants, artists, small business owners. You know if we don't make room for those kind of people the city becomes less attractive, not necessarily more attractive. So yeah I think the neighborhood might feel a little bit different but if done right you know the quality of life definitely can improve. Lots of local shops, better transit, more energy, maybe more funding too.

But it's also a chance to do things a lot smarter. If we build near public transit, you know, make it easy to walk or bike, we don't have to add much to the gridlock. In fact, we might actually reduce it. More people living close together where they work or shop means, you know, fewer cars on the road. The real issue is making sure our transit system keeps up, like BART and MUNI and buses, you know, things like that, you know, bike lanes, in fact. They need to grow with the city, you know, upzoning can help or hurt, you know, it really just depends on whether, you know, you build just more units or you actually invest in how people move and travel.

It tells folks, hey, this isn't just for them, it's for all of us. It's really that strong effect, but it grows slowly. It's earned, and it's not handed out freely. And when people see that others like them are being heard and considered, support starts to take a foot, and they start feeling they're taken advantage of, and it's lining the coffers of the big boys, you know, they're likely not to support.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Diversity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, the connection between, you know, housing affordability and support for upzoning is a pretty strong connection, but, you know, it's built on what people believe upzoning will actually do. Folks see upzoning as a way to bring prices down and create homes they or their kids can afford support increases like myself. That's a true positive fact. But if they think it just leads to more high-end buildings and higher rents, then support's going to drop. And I've seen that before. And that's definitely a negative effect. So, you know, the effect is strong either way. It just depends on whether people trust that upzoning is part of a solution and not just a part of the problem.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Housing affordability and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Housing affordability → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, the effect of taller buildings on support for up-zoning is almost immediate. People are going to react fairly quickly when something new shows up on their block and it's a tall one. Now for a lot of folks, it has a negative decreasing effect, you know, not in my backyard. They worry about shadows, parking, views, and the feel of the neighborhood changing too fast. That reaction can be very, very strong, especially if they weren't part of that decision. But over time, you know, if these buildings bring real benefits like affordable homes or new local shops, opinions, you know, can't shift still. That first impression, you know, it hits hard. So yeah, the effect is immediate and strong, usually negative, unless the city does a really good job of selling it or trying to explain the why and showing the who it's for, you know, how's it going to benefit me.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Taller buildings on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Taller buildings → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well you know traffic congestion has a negative decreasing effect on support for upzoning and that's just a reality when people already feel stuck in traffic and just sitting there. The idea of adding more people to the area makes them nervous you know it's just a gut reaction and it's a very strong one and even if upzoning brings benefits you know folks worry it'll just make the roads worse. So unless the plan includes real transit improvements such as bike lanes, walkable options, more efficient bus routes, extension of BARTA metro your support tends to wane. So yeah it's a strong negative effect unless you fix the traffic story first.
qaPairs.question: Does Traffic Congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Traffic Congestion → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, the effective community knowledge on support for upzoning takes time to develop. People don't just flip their opinions overnight, like it's a dream. They need to understand that what's being proposed, to analyze it, to absorb it, and how's it going to affect them, whether it's fair, it's all about me, and how's it affect me? When folks are informed and feel included, you're going to have a positive increasing effect on that support. They're more open to change when they know what's the reason behind it and how they see benefit as a community, as a whole, not just for developers. It's a strong effect, but it builds slow. Trust does take time. It doesn't build overnight. Good information, shared early and often, is what really makes the difference.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Community knowledge on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Community knowledge → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: You know, urban density can cut both ways. In areas that already feel crowded, it tends to have a negative effect, a decreasing effect on support for upzoning. You know, people often worry about, you know, way too many people, and there's not enough parking, pressure on schools or transit, that direction is often immediate and strong, you know. Being a lifelong resident of San Francisco, I can definitely tell you, you know, that reaction, if they see that, you know, they're not going to like it. But in places where density brings walkability, better public services, and local business, the effect can be positive, increasing, you know, especially when people see the benefits for themselves. So the effect of density on support for upzoning is significant. It's rather strong either way. It just really depends on whether people feel the growth is helping or overwhelming their particular neighborhood.
qaPairs.question: Does Urban density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Urban density → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, the effect of sustainable development and support for upzoning takes time to develop. People need to see the proof, energy efficient buildings, green space, better transit, you know, less waste. It's not something that clicks right away, but once you see it's in action, it has a positive increasing effect. When upzoning is tied to sustainability, folks are definitely more likely to support it, especially if, you know, they care about climate, you know, quality of life and especially long-term planning.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Sustainable development on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Sustainable development → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: You know, construction jobs usually do have a positive, increasing effect on support for upzoning. You know, especially in working class communities or places hit hard by unemployment, you know, people see jobs, they may see paychecks, you know, see local hiring as a big win, you know, when you have increasing jobs available, that's always a win for any community. But it's not a huge driver on its own, you know, it's got a moderate effect. Folks will care more about what's being built and who can live there and the sustainability and its impact on their daily life. So yeah, construction jobs do help build support, but, you know, the flip side, it only, you know, if you look at the big picture, you know, it has to feel fair and beneficial.
qaPairs.question: Does Construction jobs have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Construction jobs → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: You know, the effect of displacement on support for upstarting is quite immediate. It's negative. When long-term residency neighbor is forced out, you know, that trust breaks down quickly. And people don't wait to see the long-term benefits, they react to what they see now and what's happening now. It's a very strong effect. You know, displacement makes folks feel like the city is being taken from them, you know, not shared. And especially those, you know, who have been there a long time. Even if the policy has good intentions, if people see their community as being erased in support for upzoning, it disappears very quickly. But unless, you know, protections are built from the start, displacement kills trust and definitely support within it.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Displacement of longtime residents on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Displacement of longtime residents → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: You know, the effect of memory and history or support for upzoning takes time to develop. We've always stressed that. It's built for the people and it's built into the people. The stories, the landmarks, the way a place feels because of who's lived there. For many, it has a negative effect on upzoning, especially if the change feels rushed and if it's incomplete, like it's swiping out the past. People want to protect what they've known and loved for so many years. That feeling can be strong, especially in neighborhoods with deep roots. But if upzoning respects that history, you know, not just with plaques and trophies and all those kind of things, but with actual real care, the resistance can soften over time. Still, memory runs deep, and if you ignore that, the support fades very, very quickly.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Community memory and history on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Community memory and history → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, it's very confident, I'm very confident that, you know, changes in access to opportunity, ATO, you know, leads to changes in support for upzoning. When people see that, you know, upzoning brings real opportunities, like better schools, shorter commutes, more parks and recreation, job access, retail, safer housing, you know, support will increase and that's a positive effect and it can be strong, especially in underserved communities, you know, but the key is who gets that access, you know, if only new arrivals or wealthier folks with big pockets benefits and then only benefits them, then, you know, support dwindles fast. So, yes, access to opportunities has a big impact, but also not only if it's shared.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Access to Opportunity lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Access to Opportunity → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, housing policy usually has a positive increasing effect on support for upzoning. If the policy is clear, fair, and it actually helps people and they believe it. When folks see strong policies that protect renters, fund affordable housing, and prevent displacement, strong support for upzoning does go up, and that's a very strong effect. Reviewed policy builds great trust, but when housing policy is weak, confusing, and feels like it only helps the developers with thousands of millions of dollars, the support drops quick like a rock, drop it like it's hot. So while the effect is significant, it really depends on how well the policy is written and enforced.
qaPairs.question: Does Housing Policy have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Housing Policy → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, the main cause of increased housing availability, you know, right now are upzoning and relaxed building regulations, you know, letting more units get built faster without really thinking about things. You know, so I guess that can be a positive increasing effect, but I'm fairly certain about this. It's happening in real time across the, you know, cities, you know, public and private investment in affordable housing, more funding, more units, et cetera, you know, positive increasing effect, you know, I'm only certain depends on whether funding actually reaches the right projects, you know, higher interest rates, slowing demand. Some buyers are sitting it out, you know, leaving more rental openings, you know, a mixed effect, you know, can increase availability, but not necessarily affordability. I am somewhat certain it's a side effects. It's not a longterm fix, remote work shifts, you know, fewer people needing to live in these high cost urban dense areas, you know, positive, you know, it has a positive increasing effect in some cities, neutral in others, you know, moderate certainty still is playing out. So, yes, multiple things are pushing availability up, but, you know, only those of them are truly sustainable or equitable and, you know, housing doesn't stay down for long, especially in San Francisco.
qaPairs.question: What do you think are the main causes of Increased housing availability, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: Well, you know, the relationship between community trust and support for upzoning is fairly, fairly strong. Maybe one of the strongest there is when people trust the city and planners and the process and the support for upzoning does increase, you know, that's a positive effect. And it grows fast when folks get heard, respected and protected. But when trust is broken, you know, when decisions are made behind closed doors or people get displaced without wanting it and feel like things to come down behind their back, you know, support really drops fast and hard. That's a negative decreasing effect and it's just as strong as if not stronger. So yeah, you know, community trust doesn't just influence support for upzoning, it really decides it.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Community trust and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Community trust → Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Changes in upzoning policies usually happen because of a mixed pressure of politics and public needs. And the main causes generally tend to be, I think, housing shortages and an affordability crisis. That's definitely a strong influence. You know, enough people can't afford to live in a city, something's got to give to get priced out. So, you know, you get political leadership and city priorities that are definitely a strong influence. A mayor or city council pushing for change can shift that policy or maybe just entirely block it. I think, you know, community pressure and advocacy is a moderate to strong influence. If neighborhoods organize and push for more inclusive housing, it can definitely move the needle. You know, also, you know, especially when the media picks it up. And then you get the developers and business interests, strong influence, but sometimes controversial. They bring money and momentum, but not always the community, it's a buy-in. And then you get the state or federal mandates, strong and growing influences, especially in cities like California, you know, where the state is stepping in when the city calls or city solve. So yeah, most of these influences are strong. The question is whether they're being used to help everyone or just a few.
qaPairs.question: What causes changes in Upzoning policies? Are these influences strong or weak?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Please proceed.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I'd prefer to use textual responses.

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Let's proceed with text input.

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
I do, yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Sounds good to me.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
I will endeavor to try.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
It's a necessary evil. There's only so much space and there's a fluxing amount of people living in the city.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
It certainly affects the skyline and the stunning vistas but if it gets people off thte streets, all the better.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
It would almost certainly decrease the number of homeless. Alongside government programs to allow affordable housing.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
As long as the new buildings aren't too modern and brutalistic in design, I see no problem.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
Little effect. It's a very walkable city.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
More affordable housing assistance to individuals and families would help.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
I see no concerns in that particular arena.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
Less people on the streets and more housed people would foster economic growth.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
The more people housed the higher the property values. Simple as that.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
If affordable housing is available, subsidized by the state, the better off the city will be.

How confident are you that changes in Upzoning policies lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
A net positive effect over the long-term.
What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
How it might affect the unique aesthetics of this city.

Is the effect of Stunning vistas on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It could easily go either way. Dependent on how it's handled.

Is the effect of Housing affordability on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It will take at least a decade to know for sure.

How would you describe the relationship between Neighborhood character and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Neighborhood character is important, but so is housing the unhomed.

Would small changes in Walkability lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
No effect at all. I've been a resident for years and I've never owned a car.

Is the effect of Affordable Housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong positive effect over the long-term.

Is the effect of Housed People on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong positive effect. The more housing, the more affordable housing will be.

How confident are you that changes in Property Values lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
As long as this plan is handled with a measured hand, it's a net positive in the long run.

Does City Prosperity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
City prosperity is severly affected by homelessness. This would address the issue directly.
What factors do you think influence Limited urban space, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Lack of housing is the key factor. High-density housing would make a difference.

How would you describe the relationship between Immediate vs. gradual development of effect and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
All development decisions would take years to pay out in dividends. At the end of the day it would have a strong effect.

How would you describe the relationship between Positive Effect and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Upzoning, as you describe it, can only benefit the city if carefully handled.

Would small changes in Positive long-term impact lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Positive long-term impact is the only way to approach it. It's not going to happen overnight.

Does Homelessness have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Homeless is the greatest threat facing the city today. Alleviating that would only have a positive effect.

Does Homelessness have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

sure

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I would rather type.

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
yes

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
ok
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
I'm ready.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I support it because our city has a housing crisis. The rent is also way too high. Increasing supply should bring the price down.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

It should bring infrastructure improvements to support the influx of new residents. It would bring more customers to the nearby business districts. Some negatives I could see would be traffic and parking, but I think new housing will put pressure on the city to improve public transportation.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I think it will increase affordability with increased supply.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
It would make neighborhoods more lively and active. I could also see overcrowding happening if we don't build the infrastructure to support more people.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
I think it will initially have a negative impact because we would have more people, but I think it will improve as the city is forced to improve it.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
I think it should be based on what the area can support. Is there enough parking and public transportation to support more people. I think the government should have a role in regulating this.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
It's more efficient to have people in a dense area than to have sprawl, so I don't think it will have a net negative impact.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

I think it will improve the business districts because there will be more clientele. I could also see it having a negative impact if wealthier people move into a poorer neighborhood and this lets local businesses push prices up.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
I think we need to make sure that current residents won't get pushed out by rising prices and gentrification. We need to make sure they don't get pushed out.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I think it needs to be an important factor. We can't just have a city built for the wealthy. We need people from all socioeconomic strata to function. People need to be able to live where they work.
What factors do you think influence Housing crisis, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I think the housing crisis is influenced by low supply. As the city has grown in the last few decades, building hasn't kept up. It's created a housing deficit and the problem is worsening as the city grows. Right now the economic situation isn't great and that's reducing growth, but when the economy recovers and we have more job creation, we will need more housing.

Would small changes in Housing crisis lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Is it a positive influence (increases) or negative influence (decreases)? How strong is this effect?
At this point, it would take larger shifts because of how far we've fallen behind in suppy versus demand. Small changes would be a positive but it's not enough.

How would you describe the relationship between Housing crisis and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Is it a positive influence (increases) or negative influence (decreases)? How strong is this effect?
I think it's increasing because people are upset with the situation with high rents.

Would small changes in Increased supply lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it would need take larger shifts and I think it would increase support.

Does Neighborhood character have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think neighborhood character has a negative on support because current residents usually want to keep things the way they are. They don't want more people or more traffic.

Would small changes in Increased population lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think small changes would still have a large shift in increasing support because we're already behind on supply.

How would you describe the relationship between Local government role and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't think local government supports upzoning much. It's a weak connection. Proposals for upzoning always face a lot of opposition.

How confident are you that changes in Efficiency lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
What do you mean by efficiency?

How confident are you that changes in Improved business districts lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Improved business districts lead to increase in support because we want to see businesses thrive and livelier neighborhoods.

Is the effect of Gentrification on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it takes time to develop as more people with money move in. I think it can have a strong effect over time.

How would you describe the relationship between Preventing displacement of current residents and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Displacement has a strong negative effect on support for upzoning.

Is the effect of Socioeconomic Diversity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it depends on how you upzone. If it's market rate, then I think it decreases support because it tends to disfavor people in lower socioeconomic circumstances.

Does Low supply have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Low supply has a positive strong effect on support because low supply causes rent to be higher.

How confident are you that changes in Small changes lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think small changes have a weak positive effect.

Does Increase in Affluent Population have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it has a large negative effect because most people do not like gentrification.

Does Increase in Affluent Population have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (🎤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I would like to type my responses

For text input, click the message icon (💬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (➤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Yes I would like to try text input

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes I do

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Ok
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
I am ready for the first question
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I support upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing. It increases the housing supply and makes it cheaper for everyone.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
A major positive impact is reduced housing costs due to the supply increasing. The biggest negative impact would be overcrowding in a neighborhood.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I think upzoning policies would make housing cheaper.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
It would make the neighborhood more vibrant as there are more people. However, traffic would increase and there is potential for more conflict.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
It would increase traffic in cities due to the increased number of people.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
Local government should be responsible for making sure housing is built in a safe manner. Buildings need to be strong and secure.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
Increasing urban density has potential to strain the electric grid and water supply. This will mean that the environment might be harmed as those resources are expanded.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
Changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing will help local businesses. Restaurants will have more people to serve.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
Current residents need to be assured that they will still have a place in the neighborhood. Future residents need to feel comfortable and safe.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
Zoning and housing policy needs to be fair to everyone. There should not be discrimination in deciding who gets to live where.

Does Higher density housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Higher density housing has a positive effect on support for upzoning. People that want to build higher density housing want to increase the areas where they can build.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Increases in support for upzoning might come from businesses that are looking for more customers. Decreases in support for upzoning might come from residents that are complaining about traffic and congestion.

Would small changes in Reduced housing costs lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Small changes in reduced housing costs will lead to an increase in support for upzoning. People that feel like housing is too expensive will want to increase the supply.

Is the effect of Cheaper housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The effect will take time to develop. It has a negative strong effect.
How confident are you that changes in Vibrancy lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Changes in vibrancy will lead to a strong change in support for upzoning. People that are experiencing growth in their neighborhood will want more.

How would you describe the relationship between Increased population and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The relationship is a strong connection. More people means that more housing is needed.

Is the effect of Safety of housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It takes time to develop. There is a positive effect as if the housing is safe more people will want to live there.

How confident are you that changes in Electric grid expansion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I am very confident. If the electric grid can support it more housing can be built. It is a strong positive effect.

Is the effect of Local businesses on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It takes time to develop. Local businesses want customers and an increase of housing means a higher population.

How confident are you that changes in Fairness in Zoning lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I am not confident that changes in fairness in zoning will lead to an increase in support for upzoning.

How would you describe the relationship between Non-Discrimination and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It is a weak connection. I think that housing pricing is a bigger factor.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Increases in upzoning policies might come from an increased population that needs housing.

Is the effect of Increase in support for upzoning on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It is immediate and has a strong effect.

How confident are you that changes in Negative effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It is a negative effect and is very strong.

Would small changes in Strong Connection lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It would lead to an increase in support for upzoning. People that feel connected to each other will want to live together.

Is the effect of Necessity for More Housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It is immediate. People need more housing immediately and will support upzoning.

How confident are you that changes in Positive effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I am not confident that it will lead to a change in support for upzoning.

What might lead to increases or decreases in Increased housing density, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
An increase in population will lead to a strong increase in upzoning.

What might lead to increases or decreases in Increased housing density, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: I greatly support any policies that would allow expansion of housing, in any neighborhood. As a city (and a state) we are dreadfully behind the curve on housing compared to other large cities.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: The most positive impact would be the ability to increase the supply of housing and lower the absurd cost of living in San Francisco.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: I think that it would naturally lower the prices in urban areas. If we can choose to live in a slightly further area in our small city, but not live in a filthy, crime infested area for the same price, most people would gladly do so.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer: I think that in some ways it would be a negative, but I think the positives, such as the increased patronage of local businesses and support for the cities economy would be worth it.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: I think it would put strain on them at first, but we also need to adapt and grow with the times. Our public transportation is acceptable for a city of our size, but abysmal for a city with our capital. We would be forced to address both public transportation and traffic as a result.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: I think they should play some role, but there must be a way to advance development and not allow the government or certain groups stall plans or policy changes.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: I think that we would need to preserve the natural parts of the city, including parks, but I'm not overly concerned with environmental issues given how bad our housing situation is.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: An influx of people and families would lead to increased patronage, but might also lead to an uptick of crime.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: I think it should be weighed in favor of future residents. Lowering the cost of housing in the city would benefit both sides and should be the main focus.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: I think that they play a role, but should play a more pronounced one. If we were able to develop more housing and lower the cost of living here, people that are the backbone of the city might actually be able to afford to live here, thus providing access to opportunity.

Cost of housing/living decreases - strongly positive
Increased strain on public transportation - slightly negative
Increased congestion - slightly negative
qaPairs.question: What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: Expanding upon the quality of living question. I think some people who are not supporters for housing development have specific issues like noise, their view, certain groups being invited into their neighborhood that should be asked about directly.
